PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Regina Wilks
Address: 426 E.S. Saskatoon Sask.
Birthplace: Hungary, Austria

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? Macdonald Lake
Where had you been living before that? Regina, Sask.
For how many people did you prepare meals? At least for 2 of us.
How far was it to your nearest store? From 4 to 5 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a week.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? 48
In what quantities did you buy it? 60 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.00
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? 30 miles. What year? 1915
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 6 cents
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? None Whole Wheat? None Farina? Yes
Other? None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? None

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Yes. Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Yes.

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Around 1925.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? None.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? In the 30s.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes, both ways.

To what extent? All we can for winter use for a family of 5.

Did you make your own vinegar? None.
